explanation: The report is correct. There are code paths that increment ioff based on comparisons of buf[0] and buf[1] without first guaranteeing that pp->buffer_pos >= the number of bytes being consumed. After those increments the code unconditionally does if (ioff > 0) { memmove (buf, &buf[ioff], pp->buffer_pos - ioff); ... } — the memmove length is computed as pp->buffer_pos - ioff (size_t). If ioff > pp->buffer_pos that subtraction underflows to a very large size and the source pointer &buf[ioff] points past the buffer, leading to out-of-bounds access by memmove. For example, in RN_OptN / RN_Full branches the code can do ioff++ when only 0 bytes are present in the buffer (pp->buffer_pos == 0), which yields ioff == 1 > pp->buffer_pos and thus triggers the problematic memmove. This exactly violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (string/memory functions must not access beyond object bounds).
